metadata.case_name: Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd. v. D. R. Singh

facts.text: Appellant Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd., Jamadoba, filed application under s. 33(2)(b) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 before Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Dhanbad in Application No. 53 of 1961 in Reference Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961, seeking approval for action against employee respondent D. R. Singh.
Certain industrial disputes pending between appellant and its employees under References Nos. 45, 56, 63 and 65 of 1961 at relevant time.
Application opposed by respondent who filed written statement.
Appellant urged before Tribunal that s.33(2) not necessary as respondent not concerned with pending industrial disputes; sought consideration of this as preliminary point.
Tribunal held appellant could not raise contention that s.33 not apply; if so, should withdraw application; refused to entertain plea and proceeded to merits.
Tribunal not satisfied prima facie case made out for dismissal of respondent; refused approval; dismissed application.
Order terminating services of respondent passed on December 4, 1961, to take effect from December 9, 1961.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave; more than three years elapsed since dismissal date by time of Supreme Court hearing.

legal_issues.text: Whether Tribunal erred in not considering preliminary point raised by appellant that s.33(2) of Industrial Disputes Act not applicable as respondent not a workman concerned in the pending industrial disputes.
Construction of words 'a workman concerned in such dispute' in s.33(1) and (2) of Industrial Disputes Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Application made as matter of abundant caution; s.33(2)(b) not necessary as respondent not concerned with pending industrial disputes in References 45, 56, 63, 65 of 1961; one of conditions precedent for s.33 applicability is workman concerned in main disputes; Tribunal should consider this preliminary point before merits.
Employer justified in applying under s.33 without prejudice to contention that it does not apply, given conflicting High Court views on 'workman concerned'.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal erred in not dealing with preliminary point; employer justified in applying under s.33 without prejudice to case that it does not apply, especially with conflicting High Court decisions on 'workman concerned in such dispute'; approved broader construction per Digwadih Colliery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: View that employer must decide applicability itself illogical; can raise point after precautionary application.

court_reasoning.text: Though reversing Tribunal on preliminary point in appellant's favour, not remanding due to lapse of over three years since dismissal; inexpedient and unjust to prolong litigation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant sought decision on point of law, not enforcement of dismissal.

holdings.text: Tribunal must consider preliminary objection whether workman concerned in pending disputes before applying s.33(2)(b); employer can apply under s.33 without prejudice to contention of non-applicability.
Broader construction of 'workmen concerned in such dispute' approved as per Digwadih Colliery.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Approval required for dismissal during pendency of disputes if workman concerned; preliminary issue of applicability

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed without examining merits of Tribunal's refusal of approval; preliminary point decided in appellant's favour but no remand due to long lapse of time since dismissal making further litigation inexpedient and unjust.
outcome.relief_granted: None; point of law decided for appellant but appeal fails.

key_quotes.text: It would be legitimate for an employer like the appellant to make an application under s. 33 without prejudice to his case that s. 33 did not apply.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on employer's right to raise preliminary objection after precautionary application

key_quotes.text: Such a view is, in our opinion, wholly illogical and unsatisfactory.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects Tribunal's view that employer must withdraw if s.33 inapplicable

key_quotes.text: we think it would be inexpedient and unjust to send the matter back to the Tribunal
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for dismissing appeal despite winning on preliminary point
